Heinze is of opinion (p. 44) that repetition of this kind, as serving to make the argument more imposing and impressive, was the deliberate intention of Lucretius; he also holds that the avoidance ofa strictly logical order is here an effective artifice of composition. Ι arn more inclined to believe that, if Lucretius had lived to finish and revise his poem3 we should not now find all these arguments in their present shape and order. Lucretius ar a Preacher.

‘No voice like his has ever proclaimed the nothingness of “moment- ary man,‘' no prophet so convincing has ever thundered in our ears the appalling Gospel of Death. Few minds, perhaps, that were not stiffly cased in soregone conclusions have ever met the storm of his passionate eloquence without bending before the blast, without doubting for an hour of their inmost instincts, and half believing that “as we felt no

woe in times long gone when from all the earth to battle the Cartha- ginians came‚'’ so now it may be man's best and only hope to quench in annihilation his unsated longings and his deep despair.’

Murrus: Classical Essays, p. 167.

The third and last section was described (p. xi) as a kind of sermon. lt is in fact what the Romans called a consolatio, such as it was the recognised business of philosophy to provide in time of trouble. Some works of this kind by professed philosophers are still extant: there is, for example, the treatise addressed by Plutarch to Apollonius who had lost a son ¹, and the consolatio of Seneca, addressed to Marcia, a daughter of the historiari Cremutius Cordus, who had suffered the same bereavement.
